2 factor authentication.definition: An extra layer of security used to make sure that people trying to gain access to an online account are who they say they are.

51% attack.definition: An attack on blockchain consensus by controlling over 51% of the block producing power on the network.

address.definition: Identifiant public unique d'une entité sur une blockchain.

aggregator.definition: Tool that combines multiple sources, to offer competitive options.

airdrop.definition: A free distribution of crypto assets to users.

allowance.definition: Allows an entity, usually a smart contract, the right to use a specified amount of your tokens in a transaction.

alternative layer 1.definition: Layer 1 blockchains other than Ethereum and Bitcoin.

amm.definition: (Automated Market Maker) A trade matchmaking system, based on a public algorithm.

asynchronous.definition: Communication entre plusieurs collaborateurs, où les participants n'ont pas besoin d'être présents au moment de l'envoi du message.

attestation.definition: A vote made by each validator to reach a consensus on whether to approve a transaction

autonomy.definition: The quality of governing your own actions, rather than adhering to frameworks of others.

bet.definition: Risking money in exchange for greater rewards.

block.definition: A group of transactions on the blockchain.

block builder.definition: Highly specialized validator nodes who construct blocks from transactions submitted to the network.

block explorer.definition: Search and exploration tool for blockchain data.

block hash.definition: The unique identifier for each block file. Each new block refers to the block hash of the previous block to form the single-file connected blockchain.

block proposer.definition: The validator node chosen by the network algorithm to select the next block to be added to the blockchain.

block reward.definition: An amount of native coin given to the proposer of a new valid block.

blockchain.definition: Système dans lequel un enregistrement des transactions en crypto-monnaies est conservé sur de nombreux ordinateurs à travers le monde.

blockchain apps.definition: Des applications blockchain qui vous permettent d'échanger des crypto-monnaies, d'utiliser les médias sociaux web3, de faire des dons caritatifs ou même d'apprendre sur la blockchain - comme à la Bankless Academy.

blockchain architecture.definition: The structures for how data is stored in blockchain technology.

blockchain technology.definition: Un nouveau type de réseau, hébergé par de nombreux ordinateurs. Il ajoute une nouvelle couche de propriété numérique à l'internet.

blockchain trilemma.definition: The problem describing the need for all 3 blockchain qualities: Security, Scalability, and Decentralization.

blockspace.definition: La quantité d'espace sur une blockchain qui peut être utilisée pour stocker des informations et exécuter du code. La quantité d'"espace" à l'intérieur d'un (ou d'une série de) bloc(s).

borrower.definition: Willing to pay interest to lenders in order to borrow assets.

bridge.definition: Connection that allows two different blockchain networks to communicate with each other and exchange assets.

btc.definition: Le symbole du marché pour Bitcoin.

censorship-resistant.definition: No government or company has control to determine what is or is not allowed.

central bank.definition: Une institution qui réglemente l'argent, les banques et la monnaie d'un pays.

centralized.definition: A single authority or entity controls the entire system.

centralized exchange.definition: (Échange Centralisé) Plateforme qui coordonne les échanges de crypto-monnaies contre rémunération, à l'instar d'une bourse.

centralized exchange staking.definition: Locking tokens through a Centralized Exchange to generate rewards.

cex.definition: (Échange Centralisé) Plateforme qui coordonne les échanges de crypto-monnaies contre rémunération, à l'instar d'une bourse.

chain.definition: Binds blocks of data together to form a database which cannot be altered or changed.

circulating supply.definition: Le nombre de pièces ou de jetons d'une crypto-monnaie spécifique disponibles publiquement sur le marché pour être échangés.

coin.definition: The native asset of a blockchain mostly used as a form of currency to facilitate transactions on the network.

cold wallet.definition: A type of self-custody wallet that is stored on offline hardware.

collateral.definition: A borrower's pledge of specific asset(s) to a lender, to secure repayment of a loan.

commercial bank.definition: Une banque qui gère l'argent des particuliers et des entreprises.

consensus.definition: Agreement, trust, and security across a decentralized computer network like blockchains.

consensus mechanism.definition: The method by which a blockchain network judges which transactions are legitimate, and which are fraudulent.

consensus mechanisms.definition: Methods by which blockchain networks judge which transactions are legitimate, and which are fraudulent.

counterparty risk.definition: The risk that another party may not fulfil its part in an agreement.

credible neutrality.definition: A mechanism that does not discriminate for or against any specific people.

cryptocurrency.definition: Une monnaie numérique hébergée par la technologie blockchain plutôt que par des autorités centralisées.

cryptocurrency mining.definition: Le processus de vérification des transactions de la blockchain en échange de récompenses en crypto-monnaie.

cryptocurrency wallet.definition: Une application qui vous permet de stocker vos crypto-monnaies et de les envoyer/recevoir ou de les dépenser.

custodial wallet.definition: With a custodial wallet, another party controls the private keys, thus controlling access to your crypto assets.

custodian.definition: Une institution financière chargée de sécuriser vos avoirs.

dao.definition: (Organisation Autonome Décentralisée) Une structure organisationnelle qui utilise la technologie blockchain pour automatiser le vote et la gestion.

dapp.definition: Une application décentralisée qui se connecte à des réseaux et protocoles décentralisés.

decentralization.definition: Le transfert du contrôle à de nombreuses personnes plutôt qu'à une autorité unique.

decentralized.definition: Aucune autorité ou entité unique ne contrôle le système.

decentralized exchange.definition: (Échange Décentralisé) Un protocole qui facilite les échanges sans nécessiter d'intermédiaires de confiance.

decentralized finance.definition: (DeFi) A set of self-custody finance tools, hosted on a blockchain.

decentralized money.definition: Monnaie dont les propriétés sont convenues par la communauté, plutôt que fixées par une institution.

defi.definition: (Decentralized Finance) A set of self-custody finance tools, hosted on a blockchain.

delegate.definition: Donner une responsabilité spécifique à une autre personne, par exemple la délégation d'un pouvoir de vote.

delegation.definition: Donner une responsabilité spécifique à une autre personne, par exemple la délégation d'un pouvoir de vote.

democracy.definition: A system of government where citizens exercise power by playing a key role in decision-making.

dex.definition: Échange décentralisé : Un protocole qui facilite les échanges sans nécessiter d'intermédiaires de confiance.

dex aggregator.definition: Protocol that combines DEX liquidity from multiple sources in one interface.

digital signature.definition: The unique identifier for each user that serves the function of personal stamps or physical signatures in the digital space.

earn.definition: Contributing value in exchange for rewards ; money verb on the skill cube.

epoch.definition: The time taken for a specific number of blocks to be included on any particular blockchain.

equality of opportunity.definition: A fairness principle, where everyone has the same chances to succeed regardless of their background or circumstances.

erc-20.definition: Une norme pour les jetons fongibles transférables sur Ethereum. Ces jetons sont divisibles et non uniques.

erc-721.definition: Une norme pour les jetons non fongibles sur Ethereum. Ces jetons ont un identifiant numérique unique et ne peuvent pas être copiés, substitués ou divisés.

erc-1155.definition: A standard for deploying both fungible and non-fungible tokens on Ethereum, under one optimized contract.

eth.definition: (Ether) Ethereum’s native coin. Used in staking and performing transactions on the network.

ether.definition: (ETH) Ethereum’s native coin. Used in staking and performing transactions on the network.

ethereum virtual machine.definition: The Ethereum Virtual Machine or EVM is a piece of software that executes smart contracts and computes the state of the Ethereum network.

fomo.definition: (Fear Of Missing Out) Anxiety or apprehension about not being included in something.

fork.definition: Il s'agit d'un changement radical dans un réseau de blockchain qui donne lieu à deux branches, l'une suivant le protocole précédent et l'autre un nouveau protocole.

fraud.definition: In blockchain economies: Unfair or fake transactions, used to change amounts of cryptocurrency held.

fraud proof.definition: Evidence that a transaction is invalid and that fraud has occurred.

gasless transactions.definition: A transaction that pays gas using some of the token to be traded rather than the native coin of the blockchain network.

gold standard.definition: A monetary system where a country's currency has a value directly linked to gold.

gwei.definition: A unit used on Ethereum blockchain, equivalent to 0.000000001 ETH (one billionth), used commonly to describe gas prices.

hardware wallet.definition: A type of self-custody wallet that stores private keys offline in a physical hardware device.

hashing function.definition: A function that is easy to calculate in one direction only, making it nearly impossible to reverse engineer the inputs and functionally guaranteeing unique outputs for a given input.

hodl.definition: (Hold On for Dear Life) Crypto slang for not selling crypto no matter what the market conditions are.

hot wallet.definition: A type of self-custody wallet that is perpetually connected to the internet.

inflation.definition: A general increase in prices and fall in the purchasing power of money.

intermediary token.definition: A token that is part of the middle of a trade route, not the starting or ending token.

invest.definition: The act of buying a coin/token that uses DeFi technology.

l1.definition: Layer 1 refers to a base network such as Bitcoin or Ethereum.

l2.definition: Une blockchain de Couche 2 [L2/Layer2] étend la scalabilité d'Ethereum tout en héritant de la sécurité d'Ethereum.

layer 1.definition: Layer 1 refers to a base network such as Bitcoin or Ethereum.

layer 2.definition: Une blockchain de Couche 2 [L2/Layer2] étend la scalabilité d'Ethereum tout en héritant de la sécurité d'Ethereum.

ledger.definition: The record of all transactions that have ever occurred.

liquid.definition: In blockchain economies: The ability to easily use a digital asset in trading, or use in smart contracts.

liquid staking token.definition: Tokens representing staked Ether. Holders earn a portion of staking rewards proportial to the amounts staked.

liquidity.definition: The quantity of a token available for trading.

liquidity pool.definition: A communal vault of tokens that facilitates permissionless token swaps.

lp.definition: (Liquidity Provider) Blockchain users who loan their tokens to protocols in exchange for a share in fees.

lsts.definition: Tokens representing staked Ether. Holders earn a portion of staking rewards proportial to the amounts staked.

market cap.definition: The total value of a given token, or market sector.

max supply.definition: The maximum number of coins or tokens that will ever exist for a particular cryptocurrency.

memecoin.definition: A cryptocurrency token themed on an internet meme, often with no purpose or utility.

meta-aggregator.definition: A tool that brings together other aggregators into an extra overview layer.

mev.definition: Maximal extractible value - value extracted by ordering transactions within blocks.

miner.definition: An individual who participates in validating cryptocurrency transactions and proposing blocks.

mining.definition: The process by which transactions are verified and added as blocks to the blockchain.

mint.definition: Issuing new fungible or non-fungible cryptocurrency tokens on a given blockchain.

monetary policy.definition: How a central bank manages the amount of money circulating in an economy.

money.definition: A medium of exchange, a unit of account, and a store of value, used to facilitate transactions for goods and services.

network governance.definition: Le processus par lequel une communauté décentralisée parvient à un accord sur les caractéristiques du réseau et ses mises à jour.

neutrality.definition: The principle of treating all participants equally, without bias towards any user or group.

nft.definition: (Non-fungible Token) A token with a unique ID that cannot be replicated, as compared to a fungible token like Ether that has no unique identifier.

node operator.definition: A member of the Ethereum community, running a validator node to process transactions on the network.

onchain governance.definition: Le système automatisé qui permet de modifier la structure d'une blockchain.

open source.definition: Logiciel libre dont le code source peut être consulté, modifié et amélioré par tout un chacun.

optimistic rollup.definition: A layer 2 rollup scaling solution that optimistically assumes all transactions in its “rolled up” transaction are valid until they are proven false by a fraud proof.

otc.definition: (Over the Counter) Trades made directly with private entities.

over the counter.definition: (OTC) Trades made directly with private entities.

payment channel.definition: Allows two parties to transact multiple times without the need for each transaction to be recorded on the blockchain.

peer-to-peer.definition: A transaction between two parties that does not require a middleman or controlling entity.

peg.definition: Method of maintaining value equivalence between two or more assets.

permissionless.definition: Not requiring the permission of any entity.

phishing.definition: A type of social engineering attack where the attacker poses as a trusted person or organization to trick victims into sharing sensitive information or sending them money.

poap.definition: A POAP (Proof of Attendance Protocol) is a badge that keeps a reliable record of life experiences in your wallet, like for example successfully completing a lesson.

price impact.definition: The amount prices on a DEX change due to the trade size.

private key.definition: A private key grants access to your wallet, allowing you to send crypto assets to other wallets.

proof of stake.definition: Blockchain Consensus algorithms that randomly choose a block producer based on a stake each entity has locked into the protocol.

proof of work.definition: Blockchain Consensus algorithms that rely on “work” done by miners competing to create valid blocks by proposing blocks and seeing if each one has a valid hash.

proof-of-stake.definition: A blockchain consensus method that selects validator nodes based on the amount of stake locked by the node.

public.definition: Public blockchains allow anyone to view the blockchain ledger.

public good.definition: Un bien public est une marchandise ou un service qui est disponible pour tous les membres de la société.

public key.definition: A public key is your wallet’s address. It gives others a point of reference to send crypto assets to you.

recovery phrase.definition: A recovery phrase is a list of 12 to 24 words, used to generate your wallet's public key and private key.

restaking.definition: Reusing staked Ether tokens to help secure and validate other protocols, in exchange for rewards.

retropgf.definition: (Financement Rétroactif des Biens Publics) Mécanisme de financement de projets, basé sur leur impact historique.

rollup.definition: A layer-2 scaling solution that allows for processing a high number of off-chain transactions and aggregating them in a single, larger on-chain transaction, increasing transaction throughput and lowering costs.

sandwich attack.definition: A hidden cost for users due to ordering of transactions by block producers.

satoshi nakamoto.definition: The pseudonymous creator of Bitcoin. To this day, nobody knows their real identity.

scalability.definition: A blockchain’s capability to handle a growing amount of work, transactions, and usage with minimal disruption for users.

scam-token.definition: A cryptocurrency token that is launched for the sole purpose of stealing investor funds.

scarce.definition: The state of being in short supply.

security.definition: Ability of a blockchain to withstand hacking attempts, code exploits, and economic exploits among other attacks, and continue to function as normal.

seed phrase.definition: Group of random words generated by a wallet on setup, they act as the master key to ALL accounts controlled by that wallet. NEVER SHARE YOUR SEED PHRASE WITH ANYONE FOR ANY REASON.

self-custodial.definition: A means of holding your assets where only you have access to them.

self-custody.definition: A means of holding your assets where only you have access to them.

self-custody wallet.definition: (AKA: Non-custodial wallet) With a self-custody wallet, you have sole control of your private keys, which in turn control your crypto assets.

settlement layer.definition: The “lowest” level of a blockchain that records the details of asset exchange from finalized transactions. Mainnet Ethereum is the settlement layer for Ethereum layer 2 scaling solutions.

settlement time.definition: The time need for a transaction to be confirmed.

sharding.definition: The process of splitting a single blockchain into multiple chains that all run together in parallel to increase scalability.

sidechain.definition: A mechanism that allows for the transfer of assets and transactions from a main blockchain to a separate, parallel blockchain (sidechain).

slashed.definition: A penalty applied to validator nodes for publishing fraudulent transactions on Proof-of-Stake blockchains.

slippage.definition: A change in buy price that helps your trade to execute.

slippage tolerance.definition: How much can prices change before your trade executes.

smart contract.definition: Computerized code that execute terms of a contract automatically.

social engineering.definition: Manipulating someone into sharing sensitive or confidential information such as passwords or seed phrases.

solo staker.definition: A node operator running an independent validator node.

solo staking.definition: Directly running a validator node, granting the ability to directly process transactions in Proof-Of-Stake systems.

spend.definition: Using your crypto assets to pay for goods or services.

stake.definition: The amount of a financial asset locked into a cryptocurrency protocol. It represents someone’s financial commitment to the protocol, their “skin in the game”.

staker.definition: A member of the Ethereum community, providing Ether to a validator node, in exchange for rewards.

stakers.definition: Members of the Ethereum community, providing Ether to validator nodes, in exchange for rewards.

staking.definition: The temporary commitment of a portion of your crypto into a smart contract for a specified amount of time in exchange for earning interest ("rewards").

staking pool.definition: On Ethereum: Smart contracts through which stakers provide Ether to another staker’s validator node.

staking providers.definition: A digital platform providing staking services, usually through staking pools.

swap.definition: A trade from one token to another.

token.definition: Units that can stand for assets or deeds that are built on an existing blockchain.

token allowance.definition: An agreement between a wallet and smart contract, allowing limited or unlimited access to a specific token.

token distribution.definition: La manière dont les jetons sont répartis entre les différents groupes de parties prenantes.

token pair.definition: The two associated cryptocurrencies that make up a liquidity pool.

tps.definition: A measure of a blockchains scalability, TPS is the number of transactions per second processed by a blockchain.

trade.definition: Exchanging assets or money for something valuable ; money verb on the skill cube.

trade route.definition: What is the path taken from starting token to ending token in a trade.

trade routing.definition: Planning the path taken from starting token to ending token in a trade.

transaction.definition: A record of transfer, monetary or otherwise, on the blockchain.

transaction finality.definition: The time it takes to be sure that a transaction is valid and final, meaning it won't be reversed or changed.

transaction hash.definition: The unique identifier for each transaction; it is derived from the transaction data, the digital signature of the transaction sender, and a one-time use number to avoid duplicate transactions.

transaction throughput.definition: How many transactions a blockchain can process at once, usually measured in transactions per second (TPS).

trustless.definition: La qualité de fonctionner sans avoir besoin de faire confiance à des personnes ou à des institutions. (Automatique, n'appartenant à personne).

tvl.definition: (Total Value Locked) The overall amount of asset value stored in a specific place.

validating bridge.definition: A validating bridge contract is a new design that removes the need to trust any external authority to decide if a withdrawal is valid.

validator node.definition: A computer device run by a member of the Ethereum community. As the original method of staking, it processes transactions on the network.

validator nodes.definition: Computer devices run by members of the Ethereum community. As the original method of staking, they process transactions on the network.

veto.definition: Un vote de rejet d'une proposition de gouvernance.

wallet.definition: A wallet is an application or device used to send and receive crypto assets on the blockchain.

wallet app.definition: An app on your computer or phone, used to connect to your wallet on the blockchain.

wallet provider.definition: The creator of the software you use to access your wallet. These providers do not own your wallet, but instead act as a bridge that lets you access your account on the blockchain.

web2.definition: The current state of the internet, without blockchain infrastructure.

web3.definition: Refers to the internet of blockchains, where users can self-custody their assets & data.

zero-knowledge.definition: Mathematical method that allows one party to prove a statement is valid without revealing any additional information about it.

zk rollup.definition: A layer-2 rollup scaling solution that uses zero-knowledge proofs to guarantee the validity of “rolled up” transactions while maintaining security and privacy on the layer 1 blockchain.
